subject: Re: JUnit 4.9: How to get target object from TestRule?
msgSnippet: Unless I misunderstand the example, that code would pass in an instance of the test *class*, which by itself is insufficient to determine which specific test

Unless I misunderstand the example, that code would pass in an instance of =
the test *class*, which by itself is insufficient to determine which specif=
ic test method is being run.

Stephan

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "jens_=
schauder" <jens.schauder@...> wrote:
>
> You can alway pass the reference t=
o the test into the constructor of the rule:
> 
> @Rule
> public MyRule rul=
e =3D new MyRule(this)
> 
> At least I think this should work.
> 
> Jens
> =

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Alistair Israel <aisrael@> wrote:
> >
> > =
In JUnit pre-4.9, MethodRule#apply() supplied the FrameworkMethod and
> > t=
he target object (the instance of the test class currently
> > executing).
=
> > 
> > This allowed such tricks such as dependency injection into the tes=
t
> > object, or performing pre-/post- validation on the state of the test
=
> > object.
> > 
> > In 4.9, TestRule#apply() only gives us the Description=
 object. Now,
> > maybe I haven't looked hard enough but looking at the Des=
cription
> > object alone I can't figure out how to get the instance of the=
 current
> > test.
> > 
> > Since MethodRule is deprecated, I suppose we sh=
ould just use TestRule
> > and Description from now on... so, how do we get=
 a reference to the
> > currently running test instance?
> > 
> > - alistai=
r
> > --
